Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Bellman function, Harmonic Analysis and Operator Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract (Volberg/Nazarov/Treil: 0758552/0800243/0800876)

The proposed research is at the intersection of Geometric Measure Theory and Harmonic Analysis. The main objective of Geometric Measure Theory is to find structures in seemingly unstructured, fractal-like patterns. The classical Harmonic Analysis studies wave propagation, and investigation of singular integral operators is a crucial part of the modern approach. Our continuing research, as well as the work of several other groups of mathematicians in the US and abroad, has demonstrated that new knowledge can be obtained by exploring the interaction between these two areas.

As a result of our proposal we expect to solve several important problems in Geometric Measure Theory as well as in Harmonic Analysis. The pattern recognition (i.e., problems in Geometric Measure Theory) would be advanced by using methods originating in Harmonic Analysis, and vice versa. We also expect to develop new methods to study both patterns and waves. It is expected that these newly developed techniques will have impact to adjacent areas of engineering and computer sciences such as image processing and data compression.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research was of purely theoretical nature, and the main outcomes were theorems obtained in the process as well as connections with other areas of mathematics. It also served as a training ground for graduate students and young mathematicians working under supervision of PI. 
Among the obtained results are: 
1. A series of papers about similarity of operators with analytics families of eigenspaces to backward shifts in spaces of analytic functions: such backward shifts are simple (model) examples of operators with analytic families of eigenspaces. The problem of unitary equivalence was solved earlier in a remarkable paper by Cowen--Douglas, but the question about similarity is much harder. The work was done with PI's graduate student H. Kwon. 
2. A series of papers in non-homogeneous harmonic analysis, i.e. about investigation of singular integral operators with respect to "bad" measures. In joint papers with PI's graduate student C. Liaw a new connection of two weight estimate for Hilbert transform with the perturbation theory was discovered and investigated, and new results about regularization of singular integral operators in extremely general situation were obtained. Also, investigation of a discrete models of singular integral operators lead to some new, and sometimes unexpected results. 
3. A series of papers, mostly with other PIs on the collaborative proposal, devoted to sharp weighted estimates of singular integral operators, in particular to the so called A2 conjecture. One of the approaches using by PI was based on the so called Bellman function method, where to prove a theorem one just need to construct a function with special convexity properties. A very general theorem about convex functions was obtained in the process. The PI feels that this result could be applied beyond harmonic analysis, and the it could be of help in convex analysis/convex optimization.
